questions.correct_answer: B. Medication should be stopped 6–12 h before testing

Solution:

Medication should be stopped 6–12 h before testing Repetitive nerve stimulation may provide helpful diagnostic evidence of Myasthenia Gravis. Anti-AChE medication should be stopped 6–12 h before testing.

Highyeild:

Repetitive nerve stimulation It is best to test weak muscles or proximal muscle groups . Electrical stimulation is delivered at a rate of two or three per second to the appropriate nerves , and action potentials are recorded from the muscles. In normal individuals , the amplitude of the evoked muscle action potentials does not change by >10% at these rates of stimulation. However, in myasthenic patients, there is a rapid reduction of > 10% in the amplitude of the evoked responses.

Highyeild:

It is important to develop a treatment plan based on short-term, intermediate-term, and long-term objectives for Myasthenia gravis. For example, Short term- if immediate improvement is essential either because of the severity of weakness or because of the patient’s need to return to activity as soon as possible, IVIg should be administered or plasmapheresis should be undertaken. Intermediate term - glucocorticoids and cyclosporine or tacrolimus generally produce clinical improvement within a period of 1–3 months. Long term- The beneficial effects of azathioprine and mycophenolate mofetil usually begin after many months (as long as a year), but these drugs have advantages for the long-term treatment of patients with Myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman has presented to the clinic with complaints of diplopia and generalized weakness which worsens over the day. She does not have any sensory changes, no pain, and any autonomic features. Her vitals are stable. Her mother had rheumatoid arthritis. Clinician has decided to perform a test using the agent given below in the image as there were no lab facilities at his center. After giving the IV injection there was no improvement in the symptoms. What is the correct statement?

options.label: B
options.text: Repeat the test with a high dose

options.label: D
options.text: Agent is contraindicated in this disease

questions.correct_answer: B. Repeat the test with a high dose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Repeat the test with a high dose Repeat the test with a high dose. As the symptoms are suggestive of myasthenia gravis & Edrophonium is used for diagnostic testing as an initial IV dose of 2 mg of edrophonium is given and if there is no change in symptom, the patient should be given an additional 8 mg IV.

Highyeild:

Anticholinesterase Test- Drugs that inhibit the enzyme AChE allow ACh to interact repeatedly with the limited number of AChRs in Myasthenia gravis , producing improvement in muscle strength. Edrophonium is used most commonly for diagnostic testing because of the rapid onset (30 s) and short duration (~5 min) of its effect. An objective endpoint must be selected to evaluate the effect of edrophonium, such as weakness of EOMs , impairment of speech, or the length of time that the patient can maintain the arms forward. An initial IV dose of 2 mg of edrophonium is given. If definite improvement occurs, the test is considered positive and is terminated. If there is no change, the patient is given an additional 8 mg IV. The dose is administered in two parts because some patients react to edrophonium with side effects such as nausea, diarrhea, salivation, fasciculations, and rarely with severe symptoms of syncope or bradycardia. Atropine (0.6 mg) should be drawn up in a syringe and ready for IV administration if these symptoms become troublesome . The edrophonium test is now reserved for patients with clinical findings that are suggestive of Myasthenia gravis but who have negative antibodies, Electrodiagnostic testing, or ice-pack test . False-positive tests occur in occasional patients with other neurologic disorders, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis , and in placebo-reactors. False-negative or equivocal tests may also occur.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing which has become progressive over the past 3 days. For the last 3 days, the patient was having a productive cough, temperature, and body aches. He took some antipyretics for the same. His RR-8 ,BP-100/90 ,HR-90 bpm , cyanosed , SPO2-80% . Immediately O2 was given and the patient was intubated. His past medical history is suggestive of myasthenia gravis. What additional treatment should be started?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Patient is suffering from a myasthenia crisis because of an infection in the lungs which started 3 days back.

Highyeild:

Myasthenic crisis An exacerbation of weakness sufficient to endanger life ; it usually includes ventilatory failure caused by diaphragmatic and intercostal muscle weakness. Disorders or circumstances that may exacerbate myasthenia gravis Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism Occult infection Medical treatment for other conditions The possibility that deterioration could be due to excessive anticholinesterase medication “cholinergic crisis”, should be immediately excluded by stopping the drug . The most common cause of the crisis is intercurrent infection. This should be treated immediately because the mechanical and immunologic defenses of the patient can be assumed to be compromised. The myasthenic patient with fever and early infection should be treated like other immunocompromised patients. MANAGEMENT OF MYASTHENIC CRISIS Temporarily stopping anticholinesterase drugs Early and effective antibiotic therapy Ventilatory assistance Pulmonary physiotherapy Plasmapheresis or IVIg is frequently helpful in hastening recovery.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, B, C - Option D is better than other options individually.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman diagnosed with generalized myasthenia gravis is being treated with pyridostigmine and is not responding to it properly. She has Anti- MUSK antibody positive and hence is not a candidate for thymectomy. The neurologist has decided to start her on immunosuppression. Which among the following is the most appropriate agent in this case ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rituximab Though glucocorticoids (Prednisone), Mycophenolate mofetil , azathioprine , cyclosporine , tacrolimus, and occasionally cyclophosphamide are effective in many patients with Myasthenia Gravis , either alone or in various combinations. Rituximab anti-CD-20 antibody is particularly effective in MuSK antibody–positive Myasthenia Gravis, although some patients with AChR antibody MG also respond. Options A, B, and D are incorrect

Highyeild:

Rituximab (Rituxan) Monoclonal antibody that binds to the CD20 molecule on B lymphocytes. It is widely used for the treatment of B-cell lymphomas Autoimmune diseases Rheumatoid arthritis Pemphigus Some IgM-related neuropathies. There is a growing literature on the benefit of rituximab in MuSK antibody–positive Myasthenia Gravis, which was previously more difficult to treat than anti-AChR–positive Myasthenia Gravis. The usual dose is 1 g IV on two occasions 2 weeks apart. Periodically, a repeat course needs to be administered; Some MuSK patients go 2–3 years between infusions.
